reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central move in the essay’s Section 2: the step from “many independent ways to lose large value” (fragility/product model) to “therefore mostly-great futures are unlikely by default.” If robust self-correction made big irreversible errors rare, that would substantially weaken the ‘narrow target’ picture, though the position also has a separate Section 3 argument (about fussy value functions and scale/aggregation) that would remain largely intact; hence centrality < 1. The critique’s main contribution is a plausible alternative dynamic (‘procedural corrigibility’ leading to reversible commitments and ongoing revision) showing that ‘many ways to be wrong’ does not by itself imply low probability of being >0.5; this is a real under-argued inference in the position. However, strength is limited because (i) the essay already flags navigation/optimization pressures and later essays address convergence/compromise, so the need for a dynamics story is partly anticipated; (ii) many of the cited failure modes in the position are precisely about lock-in, preference engineering, and non-obvious value loss even in satisfied societies, so “procedural corrigibility” is not shown to be a default attractor; and (iii) it doesn’t engage the Section 3 claim that many plausible moral views make >0.5 hard even given broadly nice institutions (e.g., linear scale demands, separate aggregation sensitivity to tiny bads). Correctness is fairly high: it correctly identifies an implicit probabilistic step and offers a coherent counter-model, but it overstates by implying the paper’s conclusion ‘silently assumes’ roughly independent ~50/50 success rates per dimension; the position’s product model is illustrative and not committed to that specific assumption. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Procedural corrigibility norms could cluster futures above 50% without explicit optimization
